questions.question: What is the definition of a 'process' in the context of an operating system?

options.text: A static file stored on the hard drive.
A program in execution, including its code, data, and current execution state.
A hardware component responsible for calculations.
A set of instructions written in high-level code.

questions.explanation: A process is defined as a program in execution. It is more than just the program code; it includes the current activity, data, and execution state.

questions.question: What does 'Process Management' entail?

options.text: Managing the physical temperature of the CPU.
Organizing files and folders on the desktop.
Creation, scheduling, execution, synchronization, and termination of processes.
Installing and uninstalling user applications.

questions.explanation: Process management includes the creation, scheduling, execution, synchronization, and termination of processes, along with handling deadlocks and IPC.

questions.question: What is 'CPU Scheduling'?

options.text: The process of selecting which process from the ready queue gets access to the CPU.
The process of overclocking the processor to run faster.
The allocation of hard disk space to new programs.
The manual selection of programs by the user.

questions.explanation: CPU scheduling is the process of selecting which process from the ready queue gets access to the CPU to ensure efficient resource utilization .

questions.question: Why is CPU scheduling considered a fundamental function of an Operating System?

options.text: To ensure the CPU is not idle and resources are used efficiently.
To prevent the computer from overheating.
To ensure that the graphical user interface looks pleasing.
To allow the user to play high-definition video games.

questions.explanation: Scheduling is done to ensure that the CPU is not idle, maximizing CPU utilization and system throughput.

questions.question: What is the primary role of a CPU Scheduler?

options.text: To choose the next process to run from the ready queue using a specific algorithm.
To load programs from the hard disk into the main memory.
To manage the power consumption of the processor.
To scan the system for viruses and malware.

questions.explanation: The CPU scheduler is tasked with choosing which process to run first from the ready queue using a scheduling algorithm.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the main aims of CPU scheduling?

options.text: Fairness.
Graphic Rendering.
Efficiency.
Throughput.

questions.explanation: The aims of CPU scheduling are Fairness, Efficiency, Response time, Turnaround time, and Throughput. Graphic Rendering is a function of the GPU/Application.

questions.question: In the context of CPU scheduling, what does 'Fairness' mean?

options.text: Allocating resources based on who pays the most.
Ensuring all processes get a fair share of CPU time and avoiding starvation.
Giving the CPU exclusively to the largest programs.
Randomly terminating processes to free up space.

questions.explanation: Fairness ensures all processes get a fair share of the CPU time and avoids starvation, where a process waits indefinitely.

questions.question: What does 'Efficiency' refer to in CPU scheduling?

options.text: Minimizing the amount of electricity used.
Maximizing CPU utilization to keep the CPU busy close to 100% of the time.
Reducing the file size of applications.
Increasing the speed of the system fan.

questions.explanation: Efficiency aims to maximize CPU utilization, ensuring the CPU is kept busy executing processes as much as possible.

questions.question: How is 'Response Time' defined in CPU scheduling?

options.text: The time it takes to boot up the computer.
The time required to save a file to the disk.
The time between a request submission and the first response from the system.
The total duration a process stays in the RAM.

questions.explanation: Response time is the time taken from the submission of a request until the first response is produced.

questions.question: What is the definition of 'Turnaround Time'?

options.text: The time it takes for the CPU to switch contexts.
The total time between process submission and its completion.
The time a process spends waiting in the ready queue.
The time taken to install the operating system.

questions.explanation: Turnaround time is the total interval from the time of submission of a process to the time of its completion.

questions.question: What does 'Throughput' measure in a scheduling context?

options.text: The number of processes completed within a given time period.
The amount of data transferred over the internet.
The speed of the system bus.
The capacity of the RAM modules.

questions.explanation: Throughput is defined as the number of jobs or processes completed within a specific unit of time.

questions.question: Which criteria should be MAXIMIZED in CPU scheduling?

options.text: CPU Utilization and Throughput.
Waiting Time and Response Time.
Turnaround Time and Starvation.
Context Switching and Interrupts.

questions.explanation: A good scheduling algorithm should maximize CPU Utilization and Throughput .

questions.question: Which criteria should be MINIMIZED in CPU scheduling?

options.text: CPU Utilization.
Turnaround time, Waiting time, and Response time.
Throughput and Fairness.
Process Priority.

questions.explanation: Scheduling aims to minimize Turnaround time, Waiting time, and Response time.

questions.question: What does a 'Process State' represent?

options.text: The geographical location of the server running the process.
The current activity of a process during its lifetime.
The size of the process in the hard disk.
The programming language used to write the process.

questions.explanation: A process state indicates the current activity of the process, such as whether it is running, waiting, or ready.

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid list of main process states?

options.text: New, Ready, Running, Waiting, Terminated.
Start, Pause, Stop, Rewind, Play.
Input, Processing, Storage, Output, Error.
Booting, Loading, Crashing, Updating, Saving.

questions.explanation: The standard process states are New, Ready, Running, Waiting (or Blocked), and Terminated .

questions.question: What is occurring when a process is in the 'New' state?

options.text: The process is being created.
The process is executing instructions.
The process is waiting for I/O.
The process has finished execution.

questions.explanation: The 'New' state represents the initial state where the process is being created.

questions.question: What defines the 'Ready' state?

options.text: The process has been admitted and is waiting to be assigned to the CPU.
The process is currently using the CPU.
The process is waiting for a user input.
The process is being removed from memory.

questions.explanation: In the 'Ready' state, the process is loaded in main memory and is waiting to be dispatched to the CPU for execution.

questions.question: What is happening during the 'Running' state?

options.text: The process is paused.
The process is waiting for an event.
The process instructions are being executed on the CPU.
The process is waiting in the long-term scheduler.

questions.explanation: The 'Running' state means the process currently holds the CPU and its instructions are being executed.

questions.question: What characterizes the 'Waiting' (or Blocked) state?

options.text: The process is actively computing data.
The process is waiting for an I/O operation or event to complete.
The process has completed and is exiting.
The process is in the job queue waiting for admission.

questions.explanation: In the 'Waiting' state, the process cannot execute until a specific event occurs, such as an I/O completion.

questions.question: What signifies the 'Terminated' state?

options.text: The process is suspended temporarily.
The process has finished execution and is removed.
The process is waiting for the CPU.
The process is being swapped to disk.

questions.explanation: The 'Terminated' state indicates that the process has finished execution.

questions.question: What event causes a process to transition from 'Running' to 'Waiting'?

options.text: The scheduler dispatches the process.
An interrupt occurs.
An I/O request or event wait is issued.
The process finishes execution.

questions.explanation: A process moves from Running to Waiting if it needs to wait for an I/O operation or another event.

questions.question: What event causes a process to transition from 'Running' to 'Ready'?

options.text: I/O completion.
An interrupt or time slice expiration.
Process termination.
Admission to the system.

questions.explanation: An interrupt (like a timer expiry) will cause a running process to be preempted and moved back to the Ready queue.

questions.question: What is 'Preemptive Scheduling'?

options.text: A method where a process keeps the CPU until it finishes.
A method where the OS never intervenes.
A method where a running process can be temporarily suspended by the scheduler.
A method used only in batch systems.

questions.explanation: Preemptive scheduling allows a running process to be temporarily suspended (preempted) if a higher priority process arrives or a time slice ends.

questions.question: Which of the following algorithms is typically PREEMPTIVE?

options.text: First Come First Serve (FCFS).
Round Robin (RR).
Standard Shortest Job First (non-preemptive).
Batch Processing.

questions.explanation: Round Robin is a classic preemptive scheduling algorithm that uses time slices.

questions.question: What is 'Non-preemptive Scheduling'?

options.text: The OS forces processes to stop randomly.
A process releases the CPU only after completion or waiting.
Processes share the CPU in small time slots.
It is used in modern real-time systems exclusively.

questions.explanation: In non-preemptive scheduling, once a process gets the CPU, it keeps it until it terminates or switches to a waiting state.

questions.question: Which algorithm is an example of NON-PREEMPTIVE scheduling?

options.text: Round Robin.
First Come First Serve (FCFS).
Multilevel Feedback Queue.
SRTF (Shortest Remaining Time First).

questions.explanation: FCFS is a non-preemptive algorithm; the first process to arrive runs to completion before the next one starts.

questions.question: How does FCFS (First Come First Serve) scheduling work?

options.text: It schedules processes based on their size.
It schedules processes in the order they arrive in the ready queue.
It schedules processes based on priority.
It randomly selects a process.

questions.explanation: FCFS schedules processes simply by the order of their arrival time in the ready queue.

questions.question: Is FCFS Preemptive or Non-preemptive?

options.text: Preemptive.
Non-preemptive.
Both.
Neither.

questions.explanation: FCFS is strictly non-preemptive.

questions.question: What is 'Burst Time' (TB)?

options.text: The time a process arrives.
The amount of time a process requires to execute on the CPU.
The time a process spends waiting.
The time the CPU is idle.

questions.explanation: Burst time (or CPU burst) is the amount of time the process needs the CPU to complete its execution.

questions.question: What defines 'Arrival Time' (TA)?

options.text: The time at which a process enters the ready queue.
The time a process leaves the system.
The time a process is terminated.
The time the CPU starts executing the process.

questions.explanation: Arrival time is the specific time when a process enters the ready queue.

questions.question: What is 'Completion Time' (CT)?

options.text: The time when a process is created.
The time at which a process finishes execution.
The time the process is interrupted.
The total duration of the burst.

questions.explanation: Completion time is the point in time when the process finishes its execution completely.

questions.question: What is the formula for Turnaround Time (TT)?

options.text: TT = Completion Time - Arrival Time.
TT = Arrival Time - Burst Time.
TT = Completion Time + Waiting Time.
TT = Burst Time - Waiting Time.

questions.explanation: Turnaround time is calculated as Completion Time minus Arrival Time (TT = CT - AT), or Waiting Time plus Burst Time.

questions.question: What is the formula for Waiting Time (TW)?

options.text: TW = Arrival Time + Burst Time.
TW = Completion Time - Waiting Time.
TW = Turnaround Time - Burst Time.
TW = Response Time + Arrival Time.

questions.explanation: Waiting time is the total Turnaround Time minus the Burst Time (TW = TT - TB).

questions.question: How is Response Time (RT) calculated?

options.text: RT = Completion Time - Arrival Time.
RT = First CPU allocation time - Arrival time.
RT = Burst Time - Waiting Time.
RT = Waiting Time + Burst Time.

questions.explanation: Response time is the time from arrival until the first time the CPU is allocated to the process.

questions.question: How is Average Turnaround Time calculated?

options.text: Sum of all burst times divided by 2.
Sum of turnaround times of all processes divided by the number of processes.
The turnaround time of the last process.
The average of arrival times.

questions.explanation: The average is found by summing the Turnaround Times of all processes and dividing by the total count of processes.

questions.question: How is Average Waiting Time calculated?

options.text: Sum of waiting times of all processes divided by the number of processes.
Wait time of the first process divided by the last.
Sum of burst times minus sum of arrival times.
Total completion time divided by process count.

questions.explanation: The average is found by summing the Waiting Times of all processes and dividing by the total count of processes.

questions.question: What is the function of the Long-term Scheduler?

options.text: It decides which processes are admitted into the ready queue.
It switches the CPU between processes every millisecond.
It handles interrupts from I/O devices.
It removes processes from memory.

questions.explanation: The long-term scheduler determines which programs are admitted to the system for processing (New -> Ready) .

questions.question: What is the function of the Short-term Scheduler?

options.text: It creates new processes.
It selects which ready process executes next on the CPU.
It manages the hard disk storage.
It saves process data to a log file.

questions.explanation: The short-term scheduler (or CPU scheduler) selects a process from the ready queue to execute on the CPU.

questions.question: What is the function of the Medium-term Scheduler?

options.text: It formats the hard drive.
It suspends and resumes processes (swapping) to manage memory.
It schedules the booting of the OS.
It controls the speed of the mouse.

questions.explanation: The medium-term scheduler removes processes from memory (swapping out) and reintroduces them (swapping in) to manage the degree of multiprogramming.

questions.question: Why is efficient process management important?

options.text: It allows the computer to run without a power source.
It eliminates the need for antivirus software.
It enables multitasking, efficient CPU usage, responsiveness, and stability.
It increases the physical clock speed of the processor.

questions.explanation: Process management is crucial for enabling multitasking, ensuring the CPU is used efficiently, providing system responsiveness, and maintaining stability.

questions.question: What is the main drawback of FCFS scheduling?

options.text: It is too complex to implement.
It causes high context switching overhead.
It never allows a process to finish.
It may cause long waiting times (convoy effect) for short processes.

questions.explanation: FCFS can result in the 'convoy effect', where short processes get stuck waiting behind a long process, leading to high average waiting times.
